summary: Did anyone else notice that while the rest of the hoco cast looks pretty much the same, there have been intentional efforts to...
body:
Did anyone else notice that while the rest of the hoco cast looks pretty much the same, there have been intentional efforts to make Flash look older (longer hair, mustache/goatee thing)?

It could mean nothing, but I’m hoping wondering if Flash survived the snap and is a chaperone on the trip. Can you imagine how insufferable he would be?

title: sleepless nights
body:
• also available on ao3
  • post-endgame / fix-it / hurt/comfort / irondad
  • word count: 1827

It starts like this: it’s one a.m. – he put Morgan to bed hours ago, and Pepper’s reading something on the couch in the living room; Tony plans on finishing some work in the lab and then coming back up to spend some time with her before she gets tired of waiting and goes to bed, but then his phone buzzes in his pocket. When he fishes it out and reads it’s a call from Karen, his heartbeat instantly picks up; after all, it took Tony only a handful of weeks after meeting the kid to learn that when it comes to him and calls in the middle of the night, most of the time it’s a wise thing to expect the worst.

“Karen, cancel call! Cancel call! Cancel–”

There it is.

“What the hell is going on?”

“ca– oh heeey, Mr. Stark!”

“Karen, run his vitals for me,” he says without a beat of hesitation, not even bothering to ask Peter directly – he knows the kid will just try to avoid the question.

“Peter’s vitals are currently normal and stable,” Karen supplies helpfully. “However, you’ve been called since it is past his curfew, and the Bedtime Protocol has been activated.”

“Seriously?” comes Peter offended voice from the background, and it becomes louder as Karen’s voice drowns out. “It’s not that late-”

“It’s almost two in the morning, you have to be up at seven and you have a quiz tomorrow,” Tony scolds, wishing the kid was able to see his glare through the phone call. “What are you doing in the suit at this hour?”

There’s a beat of silence, but then Peter admits quietly, “I couldn’t sleep.”

Tony sighs. “Are you at least at home?”

“…Kinda? I’m on the roof.”

“You couldn’t sleep for real or are you just coming back from patrol? Because I can check the footage right-”

“I’m serious!” Peter exclaims. “It was, like, ten o'clock when I went to bed. I was exhausted, seriously. But then I- well, it took me a while to fall asleep and then when I did I had this really, um, weird dream and now I can’t-”

“Pete,” Tony interrupts, but gently. “Are you having nightmares?”

The other line goes silent for a few moments again, but Tony lets him have his time. He looks around when there’s a sudden noise coming from the door, but when he turns around it’s just Pepper coming in, carrying her closed book on one of her hands. He mouths Peter and she instantly smiles and nods knowingly, but frowns slightly when she checks the time on her wrist watch.

“Yeah,” Peter finally admits, and Tony hears a tiny sigh. “It’s mostly about the battle - you know. The loud noises of the explosions and - and stuff.”

Tony’s heart clenches in sympathy - sometimes he forgets that Peter is only sixteen despite the time that has passed for him and the ones who remained after The Snap; he forgets that Peter was in the middle of that mess when the guy’s intergalactical army starting shooting down at them with the intention to kill, and that Peter had been caught in the middle of it all and could’ve easily ended up among their deceased fighters even though he had just came back-

“What’s the last time you’ve slept properly?” he asks, quickly shaking the thoughts away before they can start spiralling. Peter is here and alive, so there isn’t use dwelling with the past - he only has to fix what’s wrong in the present, and right now, it seems like what he needs to do is get to his kid and reassure him that everything is fine despite what his head is telling him.

Pepper, as always, catches up on the situation soon enough. She approaches Tony to stand right in front of him and run a gentle hand from the top of his head down to his nape. You should go to him, she whispers. He nods.

“Probably sometime last week?” Peter says, then quickly regrets, “But it- it’s getting better, I swear! There’s no need to worry, I’ll be fine, I’ll try to go to bed now and sleep, I’m sorry Karen had to bother you when you must’ve been getting ready to sleep-”

“You’re not fooling anyone, kiddo,” Tony sighs, only half fond - the kid is a bad liar to the point of being concerning.

He kisses Pepper on the cheek and chastely promises to be back soon as he moves quickly around the lab; soon enough the suit is spawning for his chest to enclose his body, and he’s exiting through the back door of the house and into the chilly night sky.

“Mr. Stark?” comes Peter’s quiet voice from the still connected call. “You still there?”

“Yeah, sorry,” he says, setting the course straight to Queens right away. “I’ll be there soon, yeah? Hold on tight.”

“W-Wait, what? You’re coming? You really don’t need-”

“I don’t want you to go through this alone, Pete, and I know you haven’t been telling May,” he says, but it’s not an accusation. He just wants Pete to know that even if he’s not ready to share with his Aunt what he went through just yet, Tony will be there to make sure he’s fine until then.

“It’s just–” Peter starts, then interrupts himself. A few more seconds of silence, and then, “How long?” he asks quietly.

Tony smiles a bit to himself, then quickly checks the stats on his display. “Thirteen minutes. You good until then?”

“Yeah,” Peter mumbles. “Thank you, Mr. Stark. You– you really didn’t have to–”

“Don’t mention it, kiddo,” he replies, urging the suit to move faster. “I’ll see you in a bit.”

xx

Peter’s indeed sitting on the roof by the time Tony arrives - the place is completely deserted and quite dirty, but the kid is sitting near the edge, arms wrapped around his legs and face resting on top of his knees. He looks up when Tony lands besides him but doesn’t move, only offers him a timid smile in greeting.

“Hey,” he says quietly.

“Hey yourself,” Tony replies, lowering himself down to sit besides Peter with a small groan. Damn, he’s really getting old. “Any progress?”

“I’m still exhausted,” Peter shrugs, looking away. “Still kinda scared of going to sleep, though.”

Tony sighs, taking a moment to really look at Peter; the boy has deep and dark eyebags, which definitely weren’t there - or weren’t as bad, at least - the last time they saw each other in person. His eyes are also a bit puffy and red - he’s been crying.

“What are we working with here?” Tony asks, voice lowered down almost to a whisper as if to not disturb the quiet atmosphere that has been settled ever since he arrived. “You… said it was something to do with explosions?”

Peter nods reluctantly. “Yeah, you- you know. When they started shooting down at us,” he starts, focusing on the suit’s mask on his hands rather than Tony’s face. “I- I had the gauntlet with me when it started and- and, um, I think most of those things were aiming at me. I thought- I w-was sure they were going to get me then.”

“But they didn’t,” Tony says, wrapping a hand around Peter’s shoulders - the boy is shaking under his hold. “I know it’s something hard to digest. When- well, after New York, after I got through that hole and came back, I kept dreaming about it. I was pretty sure I was going to die then; I even tried calling Pepper, but she didn’t pick up at that time.”

Peter finally turns to look at him, eyes shining under the city’s lights. He stays quiet, knowing that the story doesn’t end there.

“I thought it was going to resolve itself eventually, if I kept avoiding the memories,” he continues, giving Peter a pointed look. “Like you probably do right now. And you might be right - but you also might not, and it might get worse. That’s what happened to me.”

“What- What did you do?” Peter inquires softly.

“I started therapy,” he says. “Believe me, that wasn’t an easy decision. It took Pepper and Rhodes a really long time to convince me, because I thought that wouldn’t change anything. I couldn’t see how talking to a stranger would make me feel better about these- fucked up things I had gone through.”

Peter nods, looking away again quietly. Fortunately, he looks thoughtful, and is not flinching away from the idea right away like Tony thought he would do.

“D-Do you think it’d work? For- for me?” he finally asks, turning around to stare at Tony with teary eyes.

“Oh, Pete,” Tony breathes, reaching up to run through a hand through Peter’s head before landing it on his shoulder again. “If you’re willing to try, of course it will. Talking about it with those around you, like we’re doing right now, will also make it better, but I think professional help is never too much. I can set you up with the one who helped me back then, what you say? She still helps me even now and then, when I need it.”

Peter nods at the suggestion, almost frenetically. “P-Please,” he says, raising a fist to wipe away a tear that manages to escape and run down his cheek. “If- If you’re saying it helps, then I will- I will talk to May first, ‘c-cause I don’t know if we can-”

“I’ll cover the expenses, kiddo,” Tony reassures him. “Don’t worry your Aunt about that, I’ll have a chat with her. Okay?”

Tony knows Peter would usually complain about it, but the kid only nods which is just another indicator of how exhausted he is. He opens and closes his mouth a few times as if to say something else, but his face ends up scrunching up and he all at once breaks down in tears.

“Hey, hey, it’s alright,” Tony pulls him in for a hug as soon as he starts sobbing, the sound being muffled against his jacket. “You will get better, hm? I promise.”

“I-I’m just s-so tired,” Peter manages to say in between sobs while barely managing to breathe.

“I know, Pete. Trust me, I know,” Tony soothes him, feeling his heart break at the sound of the kid’s devastated sobs. He would do anything to take the pain away, to make Peter forget everything he’s been through - the countless night he himself spent awake, trying everything to forget all that trauma, are still vivid in his memories and he would never wish something similar to the boy. “I’ll help you make it better. You- you can count on me, buddy.”

Peter keeps on sobbing but manages to nod against Tony’s jacket, looping his arms around the man’s torso, a silent plea for him not to let go.

He doesn’t even need to ask - Tony isn’t planning on doing so anytime soon.

I couldn’t see how talking to a stranger would make me feel better about these- fucked up things I had gone through.”

Peter nods, looking away again quietly. Fortunately, he looks thoughtful, and is not flinching away from the idea right away like Tony thought he would do.

“D-Do you think it’d work? For- for me?” he finally asks, turning around to stare at Tony with teary eyes.

“Oh, Pete,” Tony breathes, reaching up to run through a hand through Peter’s head before landing it on his shoulder again. “If you’re willing to try, of course it will. Talking about it with those around you, like we’re doing right now, will also make it better, but I think professional help is never too much. I can set you up with the one who helped me back then, what you say? She still helps me even now and then, when I need it.”

Peter nods at the suggestion, almost frenetically. “P-Please,” he says, raising a fist to wipe away a tear that manages to escape and run down his cheek. “If- If you’re saying it helps, then I will- I will talk to May first, ‘c-cause I don’t know if we can-”

“I’ll cover the expenses, kiddo,” Tony reassures him. “Don’t worry your Aunt about that, I’ll have a chat with her. Okay?”

Tony knows Peter would usually complain about it, but the kid only nods which is just another indicator of how exhausted he is. He opens and closes his mouth a few times as if to say something else, but his face ends up scrunching up and he all at once breaks down in tears.

“Hey, hey, it’s alright,” Tony pulls him in for a hug as soon as he starts sobbing, the sound being muffled against his jacket. “You will get better, hm? I promise.”

“I-I’m just s-so tired,” Peter manages to say in between sobs while barely managing to breathe.

“I know, Pete. Trust me, I know,” Tony soothes him, feeling his heart break at the sound of the kid’s devastated sobs. He would do anything to take the pain away, to make Peter forget everything he’s been through - the countless night he himself spent awake, trying everything to forget all that trauma, are still vivid in his memories and he would never wish something similar to the boy. “I’ll help you make it better. You- you can count on me, buddy.”

Peter keeps on sobbing but manages to nod against Tony’s jacket, looping his arms around the man’s torso, a silent plea for him not to let go.

He doesn’t even need to ask - Tony isn’t planning on doing so anytime soon.

It starts like this: it’s one a.m. – he put Morgan to bed hours ago, and Pepper’s reading something on the couch in the living room; Tony plans on finishing some work in the lab and then coming back up to spend some time with her before she gets tired of waiting and goes to bed, but then his phone buzzes in his pocket. When he fishes it out and reads it’s a call from Karen, his heartbeat instantly picks up; after all, it took Tony only a handful of weeks after meeting the kid to learn that when it comes to him and calls in the middle of the night, most of the time it’s a wise thing to expect the worst.

“Karen, cancel call! Cancel call! Cancel–”

There it is.

“What the hell is going on?”

“ca– oh heeey, Mr. Stark!”

“Karen, run his vitals for me,” he says without a beat of hesitation, not even bothering to ask Peter directly – he knows the kid will just try to avoid the question.

“Peter’s vitals are currently normal and stable,” Karen supplies helpfully. “However, you’ve been called since it is past his curfew, and the Bedtime Protocol has been activated.”

“Seriously?” comes Peter offended voice from the background, and it becomes louder as Karen’s voice drowns out. “It’s not that late-”

“It’s almost two in the morning, you have to be up at seven and you have a quiz tomorrow,” Tony scolds, wishing the kid was able to see his glare through the phone call. “What are you doing in the suit at this hour?”

There’s a beat of silence, but then Peter admits quietly, “I couldn’t sleep.”

Tony sighs. “Are you at least at home?”

“…Kinda? I’m on the roof.”

“You couldn’t sleep for real or are you just coming back from patrol? Because I can check the footage right-”

“I’m serious!” Peter exclaims. “It was, like, ten o'clock when I went to bed. I was exhausted, seriously. But then I- well, it took me a while to fall asleep and then when I did I had this really, um, weird dream and now I can’t-”

“Pete,” Tony interrupts, but gently. “Are you having nightmares?”

The other line goes silent for a few moments again, but Tony lets him have his time. He looks around when there’s a sudden noise coming from the door, but when he turns around it’s just Pepper coming in, carrying her closed book on one of her hands. He mouths Peter and she instantly smiles and nods knowingly, but frowns slightly when she checks the time on her wrist watch.

“Yeah,” Peter finally admits, and Tony hears a tiny sigh. “It’s mostly about the battle - you know. The loud noises of the explosions and - and stuff.”

Tony’s heart clenches in sympathy - sometimes he forgets that Peter is only sixteen despite the time that has passed for him and the ones who remained after The Snap; he forgets that Peter was in the middle of that mess when the guy’s intergalactical army starting shooting down at them with the intention to kill, and that Peter had been caught in the middle of it all and could’ve easily ended up among their deceased fighters even though he had just came back-

“What’s the last time you’ve slept properly?” he asks, quickly shaking the thoughts away before they can start spiralling. Peter is here and alive, so there isn’t use dwelling with the past - he only has to fix what’s wrong in the present, and right now, it seems like what he needs to do is get to his kid and reassure him that everything is fine despite what his head is telling him.

Pepper, as always, catches up on the situation soon enough. She approaches Tony to stand right in front of him and run a gentle hand from the top of his head down to his nape. You should go to him, she whispers. He nods.

“Probably sometime last week?” Peter says, then quickly regrets, “But it- it’s getting better, I swear! There’s no need to worry, I’ll be fine, I’ll try to go to bed now and sleep, I’m sorry Karen had to bother you when you must’ve been getting ready to sleep-”

“You’re not fooling anyone, kiddo,” Tony sighs, only half fond - the kid is a bad liar to the point of being concerning.

He kisses Pepper on the cheek and chastely promises to be back soon as he moves quickly around the lab; soon enough the suit is spawning for his chest to enclose his body, and he’s exiting through the back door of the house and into the chilly night sky.

“Mr. Stark?” comes Peter’s quiet voice from the still connected call. “You still there?”

“Yeah, sorry,” he says, setting the course straight to Queens right away. “I’ll be there soon, yeah? Hold on tight.”

“W-Wait, what? You’re coming? You really don’t need-”

“I don’t want you to go through this alone, Pete, and I know you haven’t been telling May,” he says, but it’s not an accusation. He just wants Pete to know that even if he’s not ready to share with his Aunt what he went through just yet, Tony will be there to make sure he’s fine until then.

“It’s just–” Peter starts, then interrupts himself. A few more seconds of silence, and then, “How long?” he asks quietly.

Tony smiles a bit to himself, then quickly checks the stats on his display. “Thirteen minutes. You good until then?”

“Yeah,” Peter mumbles. “Thank you, Mr. Stark. You– you really didn’t have to–”

“Don’t mention it, kiddo,” he replies, urging the suit to move faster. “I’ll see you in a bit.”

xx

Peter’s indeed sitting on the roof by the time Tony arrives - the place is completely deserted and quite dirty, but the kid is sitting near the edge, arms wrapped around his legs and face resting on top of his knees. He looks up when Tony lands besides him but doesn’t move, only offers him a timid smile in greeting.

“Hey,” he says quietly.

“Hey yourself,” Tony replies, lowering himself down to sit besides Peter with a small groan. Damn, he’s really getting old. “Any progress?”

“I’m still exhausted,” Peter shrugs, looking away. “Still kinda scared of going to sleep, though.”

Tony sighs, taking a moment to really look at Peter; the boy has deep and dark eyebags, which definitely weren’t there - or weren’t as bad, at least - the last time they saw each other in person. His eyes are also a bit puffy and red - he’s been crying.

“What are we working with here?” Tony asks, voice lowered down almost to a whisper as if to not disturb the quiet atmosphere that has been settled ever since he arrived. “You… said it was something to do with explosions?”

Peter nods reluctantly. “Yeah, you- you know. When they started shooting down at us,” he starts, focusing on the suit’s mask on his hands rather than Tony’s face. “I- I had the gauntlet with me when it started and- and, um, I think most of those things were aiming at me. I thought- I w-was sure they were going to get me then.”

“But they didn’t,” Tony says, wrapping a hand around Peter’s shoulders - the boy is shaking under his hold. “I know it’s something hard to digest. When- well, after New York, after I got through that hole and came back, I kept dreaming about it. I was pretty sure I was going to die then; I even tried calling Pepper, but she didn’t pick up at that time.”

Peter finally turns to look at him, eyes shining under the city’s lights. He stays quiet, knowing that the story doesn’t end there.

“I thought it was going to resolve itself eventually, if I kept avoiding the memories,” he continues, giving Peter a pointed look. “Like you probably do right now. And you might be right - but you also might not, and it might get worse. That’s what happened to me.”

“What- What did you do?” Peter inquires softly.

“I started therapy,” he says. “Believe me, that wasn’t an easy decision. It took Pepper and Rhodes a really long time to convince me, because I thought that wouldn’t change anything. I couldn’t see how talking to a stranger would make me feel better about these- fucked up things I had gone through.”

“I’ll cover the expenses, kiddo,” Tony reassures him. “Don’t worry your Aunt about that, I’ll have a chat with her. Okay?”

Tony knows Peter would usually complain about it, but the kid only nods which is just another indicator of how exhausted he is. He opens and closes his mouth a few times as if to say something else, but his face ends up scrunching up and he all at once breaks down in tears.

“Hey, hey, it’s alright,” Tony pulls him in for a hug as soon as he starts sobbing, the sound being muffled against his jacket. “You will get better, hm? I promise.”

“I-I’m just s-so tired,” Peter manages to say in between sobs while barely managing to breathe.

“I know, Pete. Trust me, I know,” Tony soothes him, feeling his heart break at the sound of the kid’s devastated sobs. You- you can count on me, buddy.”

Peter keeps on sobbing but manages to nod against Tony’s jacket, looping his arms around the man’s torso, a silent plea for him not to let go.

He doesn’t even need to ask - Tony isn’t planning on doing so anytime soon.

body:
Iron Kids

Summary: Harley And Peter babysit Morgan and endgame never happened. Sort of endgame spoiler for certain things but nothing big.

“Thank you so much. Every phone number you could possibly need is on the fridge. 8 o’clock bed time because she’ll be cranking if she doesn’t sleep right. You can order food. Make sure you add vegetables.”

“Tony, they got it. And DumE is right there too,” Pepper reminded Tony. He laughed a little and nodded. “Morgan, we’ll be home late so listen to the boys and go to sleep on time,” Pepper said bending to kiss little Morgan on the cheek. The girl nodded importantly.

Tony bent to a crouch and opened his arms. Morgan quickly hugged him tightly. “Do you love me 3000?” Morgan looked with a wicked smile and shook her head. Tony faked shock. “How much?”

“Uh… 73 thousand hundred,” she said. Tony laughed.

“That’s so much more! Pepper did you hear that? 73 thousand hundred. I haven’t even heard of that number it’s so big,” he said.

“Just like her daddy. Good at math. But seriously, we have to go if we’re going to make our reservation,” Peoper reminded him.

“I think I could persuade them-“ he said before stopping at her look. Best to not teach Morgan to think like that. “Okay lets go,” he said before another round of hugs and leaving.

“So you’re the kids watching me?” She asked looking at them critically after the door shut. Peter pulled away and Harley glared back. The two stared for a while. “I like him,” Morgan finally said. “Play chess with me.”

“Naw. This nerd was on the chess team. He’ll do it,” Harley said grabbing an apple. Peter stuttered softly before pulling out the board.

A half hour later the scene was tense. Harley stood leaning on the table, gazing at the board. Peter was literally sweating as he too gazed at the board. Morgan stared at her pieces for a minute before pushing a piece. She looked up triumphantly at the pair.

“Check. Mate,” she said grinning widely.

“You got beat by a kid. Tough break,” Harley said standing up straight.

“I was trying my hardest,” Peter said in earnest. Harley laughed. “Why don’t you play her?”

“I’m bored. Make me a grilled cheese,” Morgan said to Harley.

“Why don’t we just order-“

“No crust. And grape juice. I’m going to watch teen titans,” Morgan said walking away.

—————————

“This is so nice,” Tony said smiling. He rubbed his thumb across the back of Pepper’s hand. She smiled back. A dimly lit restaurant, drinking red wine, nibbling on exorbitantly expensive appetizers as a dish that was definitely not diet approved was prepared in the kitchen sounded perfect to Pepper. Tony was safe and happy and not wearing his iron man suit. The way he looked at Pepper was overwhelmingly intimate; like she was the only thing in the world.

“I love this place. Who would have known I would want to go here,” Pepper said slyly. Tony shrugged while smirking.

“I don’t know. Maybe the note on my computer. And the fridge. And when Morgan told me,” Tony replies. The waiter came by and poured more wine quietly before leaving. “Speaking of Morgan. How do you think things are going?”

“Probably really well. They’re good kids.”

———————-

“THERE’S SO MUCH FIRE!!” Harley screamed. He wildly swung a hand towel. Morgan shrieked loudly.

“Fire alarm! Where is the distinguisher?!?” Peter yelped running around the kitchen.

“Extinguisher!” Harley yelled back.

“Now?!? Now is the time to argue words?” Peter said finally opening the cabinet with the fire extinguisher. He grabbed the device and fired it at the kitchen fire. It put out the fire but also covered Harley in the white fire retardant. The other boy glared at Peter as Morgan touched the smoldering hand towel to Harley’s goopy side to put it out.

“Fire’s out,” Peter said quietly. He reached for paper towels to hand Harley one who simply put up a finger.

“Don’t. Say. A word,” Harley said wiggling the finger. “I’m taking a shower and I will be back. Do. Nothing.”

Morgan and Peter stood quietly as Harley left the room.

“He looked mad,” Morgan said. Peter nodded. Morgan walked towards her room. “I’m going to color.”

“Yeah, good idea. I’m going to watch tv,” Peter said weakly. He had the moral backbone of a chocolate eclair.

——————————

“Best chocolate cake in the city. And I’m pretty sure we’ve tried them all. Remember when you made me drive out to get some in the middle of the night. It’s a good thing I know the chef,” Tony said smiling while boasting.

“I do remember that. I was 8 and half months pregnant. Had to have it. Glad you were there,” Pepper answered as he pulled a smile from her face. They were holding hands across the table. Tony had a little color to his skin and his smiled looked genuine.

“Yeah. Me too,” Tony said. “I’m so lucky, you know? I’m not suppose to get happy endings. Wife. Kid. Love the kid. She’s great,” Tony said. He got that way sometime. Seen a different timeline where this wasn’t the endgame. Made him nostalgic.

“Just the kid?” Pepper teased.

“I mean, she’s super great. Like the best. Her mom is pretty cool too.” Pepper grinned. “Think I should call to check on them?”

“No. Peter or Harley would call. Don’t be such a worrier. Never thought I’d say that. Tony Stark is too soft to enjoy a date,” Pepper said.

“Too soft? I can be hard. Do you want me hard?”

“Tony! Not here,” she whispered laughed.

—————————-

“Friday, how do we get oil paint out of Egyptian cotton,” Peter asked Friday. Morgan smiles nervously. Mr Stark and Ms Stark were going to kill them. Hell Harley was going to kill them.

“Recommended hand sanitizer mixed with rubbing alcohol rubbed from opposite side of stain,” Friday said.

“Does Mr Stark have any?” Peter asked.

“No. The highest concentration of alcohol is vodka in the pantry. Chance of success… 27%.”

“Why do you need vodka?” Harley asked. He wore a tight t shirt and pants that showed part of his ankles. He awkwardly pulled at the pants. Morgan stared at his legs. “What? Your dad is short.”

“Those are mine,” Peter said quietly. “Morgan got paint everywhere and it wasn’t my fault because I was cleaning the kitchen,” Peter said quickly. Harley looked at Peter in a way that could only be described as murder.

“I was washing off fire extinguisher goo.”

“Propellant,” Morgan corrected. Harley sighed before laughing. A real laugh. An infectious laugh. Peter and Morgan joined in.

“Let’s scrub this bed,” Harley said and the small group went to work. Morgan grabbed scrubbing brushes from a closet. Harley grabbed the vodka and Peter started scrubbing. The paint slowly started coming out.

“What is that smell?” Happy Hogan said walking in the room. The distinct smell of alcohol burned his nostrils. He froze at the scene. “Do I even want to know?”

“Scrub,” said Harley handing him a brush.

“Scrub? Does Tony know?”

“Does Tony know,” Peter mocked scrubbing furiously. Maybe the fumes were getting to his brain. Happy uneasily took the brush and started scrubbing.

“Where is the love of my life,” Tony said walking in. The group froze. “Is that my $600 bottle of vodka on Morgan’s duvet?”

“Maybe,” Harley said. Pepper stood with her mouth slightly open. Morgan his behind Peter’s leg.

“I came in after they started this,” Happy said.

“I know. After my liquor cabinet sensor went off I checked the camera. A lot happened,” Tony said. “Fire, boys? Really? Over grilled cheese?”

“I wasn’t cooking,” Peter said quickly.

“Wow,” Harley said looking at him betrayed. “You’re lucky you’re powered. We put it out.”

“No, it’s my fault for asking you to watch Morgan. You’re both too young and irresponsible to watch her. We’ll know to hire a sitter-“

“Tony, it’s okay. They did their best and yeah, they will never babysit again, but at least they tried. Why don’t you get Morgan to bed and I’ll take care of this?” Pepper said. Tony nodded and scooped up the waiting little girl. Morgan gripped his cheeks and kissed his nose as they left the room. “Happy, you can go home.”

“Alright boys. Let’s get a trash bag for this duvet,” Pepper said. Both boys gawked as Happy left. “We’ll buy a new one. Morgan is not using a vodka soaked oil painted bed spread.”

Tony nodded and scooped up the waiting little girl. Morgan gripped his cheeks and kissed his nose as they left the room. “Happy, you can go home.”

“Alright boys. Let’s get a trash bag for this duvet,” Pepper said. Both boys gawked as Happy left. “We’ll buy a new one. Morgan is not using a vodka soaked oil painted bed spread.”

trail.content_raw:
Iron Kids

Summary: Harley And Peter babysit Morgan and endgame never happened. Sort of endgame spoiler for certain things but nothing big.

“Thank you so much. Every phone number you could possibly need is on the fridge. 8 o’clock bed time because she’ll be cranking if she doesn’t sleep right. You can order food. Make sure you add vegetables.”

[[MORE]]

“Tony, they got it. And DumE is right there too,” Pepper reminded Tony. He laughed a little and nodded. “Morgan, we’ll be home late so listen to the boys and go to sleep on time,” Pepper said bending to kiss little Morgan on the cheek. The girl nodded importantly.

Tony bent to a crouch and opened his arms. Morgan quickly hugged him tightly. “Do you love me 3000?” Morgan looked with a wicked smile and shook her head. Tony faked shock. “How much?”

“Uh… 73 thousand hundred,” she said. Tony laughed.

“That’s so much more! Pepper did you hear that? 73 thousand hundred. I haven’t even heard of that number it’s so big,” he said.

“Just like her daddy. Good at math. But seriously, we have to go if we’re going to make our reservation,” Peoper reminded him.

“I think I could persuade them-“ he said before stopping at her look. Best to not teach Morgan to think like that. “Okay lets go,” he said before another round of hugs and leaving.

“So you’re the kids watching me?” She asked looking at them critically after the door shut. Peter pulled away and Harley glared back. The two stared for a while. “I like him,” Morgan finally said. “Play chess with me.”

“Naw. This nerd was on the chess team. He’ll do it,” Harley said grabbing an apple. Peter stuttered softly before pulling out the board.

A half hour later the scene was tense. Harley stood leaning on the table, gazing at the board. Peter was literally sweating as he too gazed at the board. Morgan stared at her pieces for a minute before pushing a piece. She looked up triumphantly at the pair.

“Check. Mate,” she said grinning widely.

“You got beat by a kid. Tough break,” Harley said standing up straight.

“I was trying my hardest,” Peter said in earnest. Harley laughed. “Why don’t you play her?”

“I’m bored. Make me a grilled cheese,” Morgan said to Harley.

“Why don’t we just order-“

“No crust. And grape juice. I’m going to watch teen titans,” Morgan said walking away.

—————————

“This is so nice,” Tony said smiling. He rubbed his thumb across the back of Pepper’s hand. She smiled back. A dimly lit restaurant, drinking red wine, nibbling on exorbitantly expensive appetizers as a dish that was definitely not diet approved was prepared in the kitchen sounded perfect to Pepper. Tony was safe and happy and not wearing his iron man suit. The way he looked at Pepper was overwhelmingly intimate; like she was the only thing in the world.

“I love this place. Who would have known I would want to go here,” Pepper said slyly. Tony shrugged while smirking.

“I don’t know. Maybe the note on my computer. And the fridge. And when Morgan told me,” Tony replies. The waiter came by and poured more wine quietly before leaving. “Speaking of Morgan. How do you think things are going?”

“Probably really well. They’re good kids.”

———————-

“THERE’S SO MUCH FIRE!!” Harley screamed. He wildly swung a hand towel. Morgan shrieked loudly.

“Fire alarm! Where is the distinguisher?!?” Peter yelped running around the kitchen.

“Extinguisher!” Harley yelled back.

“Now?!? Now is the time to argue words?” Peter said finally opening the cabinet with the fire extinguisher. He grabbed the device and fired it at the kitchen fire. It put out the fire but also covered Harley in the white fire retardant. The other boy glared at Peter as Morgan touched the smoldering hand towel to Harley’s goopy side to put it out.

“Fire’s out,” Peter said quietly. He reached for paper towels to hand Harley one who simply put up a finger.

“Don’t. Say. A word,” Harley said wiggling the finger. “I’m taking a shower and I will be back. Do. Nothing.”

Morgan and Peter stood quietly as Harley left the room.

“He looked mad,” Morgan said. Peter nodded. Morgan walked towards her room. “I’m going to color.”

“Yeah, good idea. I’m going to watch tv,” Peter said weakly. He had the moral backbone of a chocolate eclair.

——————————

“Best chocolate cake in the city. And I’m pretty sure we’ve tried them all. Remember when you made me drive out to get some in the middle of the night. It’s a good thing I know the chef,” Tony said smiling while boasting.

“I do remember that. I was 8 and half months pregnant. Had to have it. Glad you were there,” Pepper answered as he pulled a smile from her face. They were holding hands across the table. Tony had a little color to his skin and his smiled looked genuine.

“Yeah. Me too,” Tony said. “I’m so lucky, you know? I’m not suppose to get happy endings. Wife. Kid. Love the kid. She’s great,” Tony said. He got that way sometime. Seen a different timeline where this wasn’t the endgame. Made him nostalgic.

“Just the kid?” Pepper teased.

“I mean, she’s super great. Like the best. Her mom is pretty cool too.” Pepper grinned. “Think I should call to check on them?”

“No. Peter or Harley would call. Don’t be such a worrier. Never thought I’d say that. Tony Stark is too soft to enjoy a date,” Pepper said.

“Too soft? I can be hard. Do you want me hard?”

“Tony! Not here,” she whispered laughed.

—————————-

“Friday, how do we get oil paint out of Egyptian cotton,” Peter asked Friday. Morgan smiles nervously. Mr Stark and Ms Stark were going to kill them. Hell Harley was going to kill them.

“Recommended hand sanitizer mixed with rubbing alcohol rubbed from opposite side of stain,” Friday said.

“Does Mr Stark have any?” Peter asked.

“No. The highest concentration of alcohol is vodka in the pantry. Chance of success… 27%.”

“Why do you need vodka?” Harley asked. He wore a tight t shirt and pants that showed part of his ankles. He awkwardly pulled at the pants. Morgan stared at his legs. “What? Your dad is short.”

“Those are mine,” Peter said quietly. “Morgan got paint everywhere and it wasn’t my fault because I was cleaning the kitchen,” Peter said quickly. Harley looked at Peter in a way that could only be described as murder.

“I was washing off fire extinguisher goo.”

“Propellant,” Morgan corrected. Harley sighed before laughing. A real laugh. An infectious laugh. Peter and Morgan joined in.

“Let’s scrub this bed,” Harley said and the small group went to work. Morgan grabbed scrubbing brushes from a closet. Harley grabbed the vodka and Peter started scrubbing. The paint slowly started coming out.

“What is that smell?” Happy Hogan said walking in the room. The distinct smell of alcohol burned his nostrils. He froze at the scene. “Do I even want to know?”

“Scrub,” said Harley handing him a brush.

“Scrub? Does Tony know?”

“Does Tony know,” Peter mocked scrubbing furiously. Maybe the fumes were getting to his brain. Happy uneasily took the brush and started scrubbing.

“Where is the love of my life,” Tony said walking in. The group froze. “Is that my $600 bottle of vodka on Morgan’s duvet?”

“Maybe,” Harley said. Pepper stood with her mouth slightly open. Morgan his behind Peter’s leg.

“I came in after they started this,” Happy said.

“I know. After my liquor cabinet sensor went off I checked the camera. A lot happened,” Tony said. “Fire, boys? Really? Over grilled cheese?”

“I wasn’t cooking,” Peter said quickly.

“Wow,” Harley said looking at him betrayed. “You’re lucky you’re powered. We put it out.”

“No, it’s my fault for asking you to watch Morgan. You’re both too young and irresponsible to watch her. We’ll know to hire a sitter-“

“Tony, it’s okay. They did their best and yeah, they will never babysit again, but at least they tried. Why don’t you get Morgan to bed and I’ll take care of this?” Pepper said. Tony nodded and scooped up the waiting little girl. Morgan gripped his cheeks and kissed his nose as they left the room. “Happy, you can go home.”

“Alright boys. Let’s get a trash bag for this duvet,” Pepper said. Both boys gawked as Happy left. “We’ll buy a new one. Morgan is not using a vodka soaked oil painted bed spread.”

title: All I Want
body:
A/N: SPOILERS FOR ENDGAME.

This is what we all deserved. What we all wanted.

The title is the song ‘All I Want’ by Kodaline. If you haven’t listened to it, do. It’s sadly, wonderfully beautiful.

Please enjoy this as much as you can. <3 :,)

Title: All I Want

Summary: Peter gets one last conversation with Tony.

 Words: 2243

“Lemme speak to the k-kid… for a moment.”

Peter glanced up, watery eyes landing on Tony’s slumped form. His arms were hugging his chest as fat tears rolled down his cheeks, leaving silvery trails in their wake before falling down into the dirt. He was shivering almost violently, though he knew it was not because of any drop in temperature. The sight in front of him alone was enough to send him into a frenzy, and it was not failing in doing so now.

Pepper nodded, biting her bottom lip and heaving a sigh before leaning forward to press a kiss to her husband’s charred forehead. She lingered there for a moment, and Peter almost felt like leaving simply to allow her more time with him… but denying that he wanted to speak to Tony would be the biggest lie in his entire existence. Pepper slowly got to her feet, eyes never once straying from Tony. He looked so… broken. So defeated. And yet he had just saved the world.

“There you go, Peter.” The woman’s voice was so soft, so quiet, that Peter barely noticed she’d spoken to him. He swallowed thickly, turning to look at Pepper and noting the sympathetic gleam in her eyes. She reached out to cup the side of his face, a watery smile veiling her dry lips for just a moment before she dropped her hand and moved past him, sobs becoming all the more audible as Hope and Okoye moved to comfort her.

He suddenly felt rooted to the spot. No sound was making its way through his ears as Peter stood, legs firmly planted on the ground, arms still locked around his trembling body, except the almost deafening pumping of his heart. His breaths were coming in short gasps, and his vision was getting blurrier by the second.

And then he spoke. “It’s alright, Peter.” Those words spilled from Tony’s mouth and made him breathe in deeply, suddenly becoming all too aware of what was going on. He felt someone behind him place their hand on the small of his back, gently pushing him forward, and when he glanced around briefly he noticed it’d been Steve. The man’s eyes were red, pools of tears welling in the bottoms of them, but he smiled faintly when Peter turned to look at him, clearly a sign of encouragement. Either that or he was trying to make him aware of the fact that Tony probably did not have much time left, so if he wanted to speak to him, it had to be now.

The moment Tony weakly lifted his arm to stretch out toward him, the kid broke, immediately rushing over to the man and falling to his knees. He grabbed his hand, squeezing it tightly, and his heart skipped a beat when he didn’t receive one in return. Though Tony was clinging on to him, it was obviously strenuous for him to do so. He was barely holding himself up as it was. “Tony-“

“I nee- need you to do me a favour, Pete.” His voice was a whisper in the enveloping silence around them, and the boy’s throat tightened as he heard the broken words.

“Of course, Mister Stark. Anything.”

Tony’s mouth was dry. He could barely speak, and yet he needed to have this conversation. “Will you look after Morgan for- for me?”

“Morgan?” Peter’s eyes narrowed the smallest bit and he absentmindedly tilted his head to the side. Doctor Strange had said they’d been gone for five years, but what exactly had happened in those five years still remained a mystery. It wasn’t like they’d had much time to talk about it since… but he’d hoped to get a chance to after everything stopped.

A small smile ghosted over Tony’s lips as he stared at the kid with drooping eyes. “A lot happened while you were g-gone, kiddo. I… I got a family. Pepper and me- we had a baby. Girl. Morgan.”

A baby? Peter couldn’t stop the light from going off in those bright eyes of his. The slightest splash of colour returned to his tear-stained cheeks and he breathed a laugh. “You did?”

Tony nodded, a look of pride briefly passing across his face. He shifted, wincing immediately at the pain that shot through the whole of his right side, and Peter’s face fell before he quickly rushed to comfort him. His hand fell lightly on his shoulder, the other still tightly gripping onto his hand, and the man immediately felt a surge of pure solace rush through him. “We did,” he whispered. His eyes shut for the shortest moment before he blinked rapidly and turned them back on the kid. “You know,” he said, “p-people keep asking me… what it’s like to be a dad.”

Peter nodded. “And what do you tell them?”

“I- I tell them that it’s no different.” He leaned his head back against the rock he was resting against, swallowing what tasted to be blood. His heart, slow as it was, sped up for the briefest of moments at the slight panicking thought that he may not be able to finish this conversation like he wanted, but he recovered quickly at the unfocused sight of Peter staring worriedly back at him. He was sure the kid had said his name a couple seconds ago. “I’m here,” he said, squeezing Peter’s hand back as hard as he could.

Peter visibly deflated, shutting his eyes and sighing in what he assumed to be relief. He nodded. “No- no different to what, Mister Stark?”

“No different to h-how it used to be… before Mor-Morgan was born. B-before Thanos.” His vision was becoming hazier by the second. His head was aching tremendously. It felt as though hundreds of knives were stabbing into the entire right side of his body. His mouth was drier than the day Rhodey found him in the desert… he was fading. He hated that he was fading. And, yet, at the same time, he praised it. “I’d already been a dad for two years,” he said quietly. “I just didn’t know it then.”

For a moment, Peter wondered if Tony really was starting to get confused. Was that what people did when they were dying? He wasn’t sure. But, suddenly, as if he’d been hit in the face by an impulse from Iron Man’s blaster, he understood. The man was talking about him. Him. It had, after all, been two years before he turned to dust that he’d met Tony. He supposed it must be seven, now. Seven years. And he had spent five of them without him. Tears were beginning to pool in his eyes once again, and he couldn’t help but sniff loudly as he shifted on one knee. “You mean that, Mister Stark?” he all but squeaked.

Tony nodded once, eyes slowly beginning to lose their light. “Yes,” he said. “Should’ve told yo- you that a long time ago.” His head slowly fell to the side, and if it wasn’t for Peter’s hand quickly reaching up and cupping the side – the burning side – of his face, he probably would have dropped off there and then. But the gentle touch against his singed skin and the coldness of the Spider Man suit brought him quickly back to it all. The last of his strength was used up entirely as he moved his free hand up to place against Peter’s next to his face. “You,” he whispered hoarsely, “are one of the greatest things… to ever happen in my life, you understand? Every… every good decision I’ve made since meeting y-you has been because I met you. You ch-changed me… in ways I didn’t even think possible.” He swallowed more blood, the metallic taste making his stomach church. “You saved my life, Peter.”

Peter’s lower lip began to tremble almost as hard as the rest of his body. His face contorted into something so painful and hopeless that Tony himself felt tears begin to well in his own red eyes. “Yes,” the kid said. His broken voice was one somebody would expect to hear from a young boy who was watching his own father die. He rapidly shook his head, tears openly gushing down his face, and bent forward, placing his forehead against Tony’s hand. “And you’ve just saved mine,” he burst out. “Everybody’s.”

The lump in Tony’s throat would never feel as uncomfortable as watching your child cry. He wanted to leap up, take that kid into his arms and cling on with every ounce of strength he had. But strength had long surpassed him. He did not have a fibre of it left. All he could do was sit there, paralysed with much more than fear, and watch as Peter broke into unrelentless sobs. He weakly shook his head, turning the hand resting against Peter’s around so he could gently grab it and pull it off his face. He held both of them in his own, waiting for him to look up before he spoke. “I did,” he said, surprised at the amount of emotion in his voice. “To give you the opportunity to be- be the greatest hero o-on this goddamn earth.” He shook his head. “I’d do it again in a heartbeat if it meant you’d get a chance to live a better life than I- I did.”

Peter wasn’t sure what kind of life he’d be living after this. What was a world without Tony Stark, after all? That man had taught him everything. He’d saved his life… in more ways than one. “I’ll miss you so much,” he choked out, and Tony heaved a rattling sigh.

“I know.” He used both hands to feebly pull Peter towards him, the kid soon getting the idea and moving the rest of the way into Tony’s arms by himself. He was still kneeling, but resting his side against Tony’s chest, and fitting his head just underneath the man’s chin made him feel better. He felt two arms wrap around him, and they were nowhere near as strong as what those bear-hugs had once used to be… but it was beyond better than nothing. “Remember what I said about Morgan, okay? She- I want her to grow- grow up w-with someone like you as her guide.”

“It could have been you.” Peter’s voice was muffled, but the man’s ears had not lost their sharpness, despite the added now-constant sound of his heartbeat drumming.

“It could never have been me, Pete-“ A sharp pain zipped through his body, and his eyes clenched shut. He swallowed – audibly, this time – the huge amount of blood which he was sure was trying to make its way out through his mouth, not back down again, and groaned, hands around Peter dropping to his sides and fists clenching.

Peter quickly sat up, wide eyes hurriedly scanning him. “Tony?” His voice broke. “Tony!”

Tony grabbed his wrist, breaths coming in short gasps as he tried to control it all. He was sure he could hear the people around him voicing their concern to each other, but he was also certain – and assured – that there were people there, such as Pepper and Steve, to stop them from trying to help him. He could not be helped. Did he even want it? His eyes shot open, immediately landing on Peter. “I love you,” he said, voice gravelly. He did not want to rush this, but he felt as though he was on a time limit here, and it was quickly coming to an end. “Always have. I’m sorry- for not showing it.”

Peter shook his head. “I knew it,” he said. “You did show it.” And he had. Every phone call made to check in on him, every hour spent out of his day working on the Spider Man suit, every penny he spent on him, every hug, every shared laugh, every smile… they’d all shown his love in the most discreet of ways, but they’d done it all the same, and Peter couldn’t have felt more grateful.

Tony smiled, and the kid tried his hardest to not be shocked at the blood that was quickly coating his lips. “I thought so.” He could barely hear his own voice, now. “Hey… thanks for all the dad practice you gave me. It really pro- proved useful.” He smiled faintly at the breathy laugh that escaped Peter’s lips.

“I’m glad,” he said, before hesitating. “Are you in pain?”

Pain. It had all gone, now. There’d been an agonising moment of it… but it’d faded. He felt… light. Like his soul was beginning to drift off, leaving the shell behind. There was no feeling of- of anything. He shifted slightly, shaking his head. “No.” Because you’re here with me. He coughed, blood dripping down from his mouth, and his face turned deathly white. Raging butterflies spawned out of nowhere in Peter’s stomach, and he leaned forward, hands coming to rest on Tony’s shoulders.

“Tony!” he called.

The warmth of Tony’s life was being swept away by the cold embrace of death, and yet this cold embrace felt welcoming. He was seconds away from it, now. He could see the light, and as soon as he touched it, as soon as his fingertips brushed across it, it turned warm. Comforting. It felt like he was going home.

“It’s been an honour, son.”

And, like the snap of two fingers, Tony Stark’s heart beat one last time.

Pepper nodded, biting her bottom lip and heaving a sigh before leaning forward to press a kiss to her husband’s charred forehead. She lingered there for a moment, and Peter almost felt like leaving simply to allow her more time with him… but denying that he wanted to speak to Tony would be the biggest lie in his entire existence. Pepper slowly got to her feet, eyes never once straying from Tony. He looked so… broken. So defeated. And yet he had just saved the world.

“There you go, Peter.” The woman’s voice was so soft, so quiet, that Peter barely noticed she’d spoken to him. He swallowed thickly, turning to look at Pepper and noting the sympathetic gleam in her eyes. She reached out to cup the side of his face, a watery smile veiling her dry lips for just a moment before she dropped her hand and moved past him, sobs becoming all the more audible as Hope and Okoye moved to comfort her.

He suddenly felt rooted to the spot. No sound was making its way through his ears as Peter stood, legs firmly planted on the ground, arms still locked around his trembling body, except the almost deafening pumping of his heart. His breaths were coming in short gasps, and his vision was getting blurrier by the second.

And then he spoke. “It’s alright, Peter.” Those words spilled from Tony’s mouth and made him breathe in deeply, suddenly becoming all too aware of what was going on. He felt someone behind him place their hand on the small of his back, gently pushing him forward, and when he glanced around briefly he noticed it’d been Steve. The man’s eyes were red, pools of tears welling in the bottoms of them, but he smiled faintly when Peter turned to look at him, clearly a sign of encouragement. Either that or he was trying to make him aware of the fact that Tony probably did not have much time left, so if he wanted to speak to him, it had to be now.

The moment Tony weakly lifted his arm to stretch out toward him, the kid broke, immediately rushing over to the man and falling to his knees. He grabbed his hand, squeezing it tightly, and his heart skipped a beat when he didn’t receive one in return. Though Tony was clinging on to him, it was obviously strenuous for him to do so. He was barely holding himself up as it was. “Tony-“

“I nee- need you to do me a favour, Pete.” His voice was a whisper in the enveloping silence around them, and the boy’s throat tightened as he heard the broken words.

“Of course, Mister Stark. Anything.”

Tony’s mouth was dry. He could barely speak, and yet he needed to have this conversation. “Will you look after Morgan for- for me?”

“Morgan?” Peter’s eyes narrowed the smallest bit and he absentmindedly tilted his head to the side. Doctor Strange had said they’d been gone for five years, but what exactly had happened in those five years still remained a mystery. It wasn’t like they’d had much time to talk about it since… but he’d hoped to get a chance to after everything stopped.

A small smile ghosted over Tony’s lips as he stared at the kid with drooping eyes. “A lot happened while you were g-gone, kiddo. I… I got a family. Pepper and me- we had a baby. Girl. Morgan.”

A baby? Peter couldn’t stop the light from going off in those bright eyes of his. The slightest splash of colour returned to his tear-stained cheeks and he breathed a laugh. “You did?”

Tony nodded, a look of pride briefly passing across his face. He shifted, wincing immediately at the pain that shot through the whole of his right side, and Peter’s face fell before he quickly rushed to comfort him. His hand fell lightly on his shoulder, the other still tightly gripping onto his hand, and the man immediately felt a surge of pure solace rush through him. “We did,” he whispered. His eyes shut for the shortest moment before he blinked rapidly and turned them back on the kid. “You know,” he said, “p-people keep asking me… what it’s like to be a dad.”

Peter nodded. “And what do you tell them?”

“I- I tell them that it’s no different.” He leaned his head back against the rock he was resting against, swallowing what tasted to be blood. His heart, slow as it was, sped up for the briefest of moments at the slight panicking thought that he may not be able to finish this conversation like he wanted, but he recovered quickly at the unfocused sight of Peter staring worriedly back at him. He was sure the kid had said his name a couple seconds ago. “I’m here,” he said, squeezing Peter’s hand back as hard as he could.

Peter visibly deflated, shutting his eyes and sighing in what he assumed to be relief. He nodded. “No- no different to what, Mister Stark?”

“No different to h-how it used to be… before Mor-Morgan was born. B-before Thanos.” His vision was becoming hazier by the second. His head was aching tremendously. It felt as though hundreds of knives were stabbing into the entire right side of his body. His mouth was drier than the day Rhodey found him in the desert… he was fading. He hated that he was fading. And, yet, at the same time, he praised it. “I’d already been a dad for two years,” he said quietly. “I just didn’t know it then.”

For a moment, Peter wondered if Tony really was starting to get confused. Was that what people did when they were dying? He wasn’t sure. But, suddenly, as if he’d been hit in the face by an impulse from Iron Man’s blaster, he understood. The man was talking about him. Him. It had, after all, been two years before he turned to dust that he’d met Tony. He supposed it must be seven, now. Seven years. And he had spent five of them without him. Tears were beginning to pool in his eyes once again, and he couldn’t help but sniff loudly as he shifted on one knee. “You mean that, Mister Stark?” he all but squeaked.

Tony nodded once, eyes slowly beginning to lose their light. “Yes,” he said. “Should’ve told yo- you that a long time ago.” His head slowly fell to the side, and if it wasn’t for Peter’s hand quickly reaching up and cupping the side – the burning side – of his face, he probably would have dropped off there and then. But the gentle touch against his singed skin and the coldness of the Spider Man suit brought him quickly back to it all. The last of his strength was used up entirely as he moved his free hand up to place against Peter’s next to his face. “You,” he whispered hoarsely, “are one of the greatest things… to ever happen in my life, you understand? Every… every good decision I’ve made since meeting y-you has been because I met you. You ch-changed me… in ways I didn’t even think possible.” He swallowed more blood, the metallic taste making his stomach church. “You saved my life, Peter.”

Peter’s lower lip began to tremble almost as hard as the rest of his body. His face contorted into something so painful and hopeless that Tony himself felt tears begin to well in his own red eyes. “Yes,” the kid said. His broken voice was one somebody would expect to hear from a young boy who was watching his own father die. He rapidly shook his head, tears openly gushing down his face, and bent forward, placing his forehead against Tony’s hand. “And you’ve just saved mine,” he burst out. “Everybody’s.”

The lump in Tony’s throat would never feel as uncomfortable as watching your child cry. He wanted to leap up, take that kid into his arms and cling on with every ounce of strength he had. But strength had long surpassed him. He did not have a fibre of it left. All he could do was sit there, paralysed with much more than fear, and watch as Peter broke into unrelentless sobs. He weakly shook his head, turning the hand resting against Peter’s around so he could gently grab it and pull it off his face. He held both of them in his own, waiting for him to look up before he spoke. “I did,” he said, surprised at the amount of emotion in his voice. “To give you the opportunity to be- be the greatest hero o-on this goddamn earth.” He shook his head. “I’d do it again in a heartbeat if it meant you’d get a chance to live a better life than I- I did.”

Peter wasn’t sure what kind of life he’d be living after this. What was a world without Tony Stark, after all? That man had taught him everything. He’d saved his life… in more ways than one. “I’ll miss you so much,” he choked out, and Tony heaved a rattling sigh.

“I know.” He used both hands to feebly pull Peter towards him, the kid soon getting the idea and moving the rest of the way into Tony’s arms by himself. He was still kneeling, but resting his side against Tony’s chest, and fitting his head just underneath the man’s chin made him feel better. He felt two arms wrap around him, and they were nowhere near as strong as what those bear-hugs had once used to be… but it was beyond better than nothing. “Remember what I said about Morgan, okay? She- I want her to grow- grow up w-with someone like you as her guide.”

“It could have been you.” Peter’s voice was muffled, but the man’s ears had not lost their sharpness, despite the added now-constant sound of his heartbeat drumming.

“It could never have been me, Pete-“ A sharp pain zipped through his body, and his eyes clenched shut. He swallowed – audibly, this time – the huge amount of blood which he was sure was trying to make its way out through his mouth, not back down again, and groaned, hands around Peter dropping to his sides and fists clenching.

Peter quickly sat up, wide eyes hurriedly scanning him. “Tony?” His voice broke. “Tony!”

Tony grabbed his wrist, breaths coming in short gasps as he tried to control it all. He was sure he could hear the people around him voicing their concern to each other, but he was also certain – and assured – that there were people there, such as Pepper and Steve, to stop them from trying to help him. He could not be helped. Did he even want it? His eyes shot open, immediately landing on Peter. “I love you,” he said, voice gravelly. He did not want to rush this, but he felt as though he was on a time limit here, and it was quickly coming to an end. “Always have. I’m sorry- for not showing it.”

Peter shook his head. “I knew it,” he said. “You did show it.” And he had. Every phone call made to check in on him, every hour spent out of his day working on the Spider Man suit, every penny he spent on him, every hug, every shared laugh, every smile… they’d all shown his love in the most discreet of ways, but they’d done it all the same, and Peter couldn’t have felt more grateful.

Tony smiled, and the kid tried his hardest to not be shocked at the blood that was quickly coating his lips. “I thought so.” He could barely hear his own voice, now. “Hey… thanks for all the dad practice you gave me. It really pro- proved useful.” He smiled faintly at the breathy laugh that escaped Peter’s lips.

“I’m glad,” he said, before hesitating. “Are you in pain?”

Pain. It had all gone, now. There’d been an agonising moment of it… but it’d faded. He felt… light. Like his soul was beginning to drift off, leaving the shell behind. There was no feeling of- of anything. He shifted slightly, shaking his head. “No.” Because you’re here with me. He coughed, blood dripping down from his mouth, and his face turned deathly white. Raging butterflies spawned out of nowhere in Peter’s stomach, and he leaned forward, hands coming to rest on Tony’s shoulders.

“Tony!” he called.

The warmth of Tony’s life was being swept away by the cold embrace of death, and yet this cold embrace felt welcoming. He was seconds away from it, now. He could see the light, and as soon as he touched it, as soon as his fingertips brushed across it, it turned warm. Comforting. It felt like he was going home.

“It’s been an honour, son.”

And, like the snap of two fingers, Tony Stark’s heart beat one last time.

You ch-changed me… in ways I didn’t even think possible.” He swallowed more blood, the metallic taste making his stomach church. “You saved my life, Peter.”

Peter’s lower lip began to tremble almost as hard as the rest of his body. His face contorted into something so painful and hopeless that Tony himself felt tears begin to well in his own red eyes. “Yes,” the kid said. His broken voice was one somebody would expect to hear from a young boy who was watching his own father die. He rapidly shook his head, tears openly gushing down his face, and bent forward, placing his forehead against Tony’s hand. “And you’ve just saved mine,” he burst out. “Everybody’s.”

The lump in Tony’s throat would never feel as uncomfortable as watching your child cry. He wanted to leap up, take that kid into his arms and cling on with every ounce of strength he had. But strength had long surpassed him. He did not have a fibre of it left. All he could do was sit there, paralysed with much more than fear, and watch as Peter broke into unrelentless sobs. He weakly shook his head, turning the hand resting against Peter’s around so he could gently grab it and pull it off his face. He held both of them in his own, waiting for him to look up before he spoke. “I did,” he said, surprised at the amount of emotion in his voice. “To give you the opportunity to be- be the greatest hero o-on this goddamn earth.” He shook his head. “I’d do it again in a heartbeat if it meant you’d get a chance to live a better life than I- I did.”

Peter wasn’t sure what kind of life he’d be living after this. What was a world without Tony Stark, after all? That man had taught him everything. He’d saved his life… in more ways than one. “I’ll miss you so much,” he choked out, and Tony heaved a rattling sigh.

“I know.” He used both hands to feebly pull Peter towards him, the kid soon getting the idea and moving the rest of the way into Tony’s arms by himself. He was still kneeling, but resting his side against Tony’s chest, and fitting his head just underneath the man’s chin made him feel better. He felt two arms wrap around him, and they were nowhere near as strong as what those bear-hugs had once used to be… but it was beyond better than nothing. “Remember what I said about Morgan, okay? She- I want her to grow- grow up w-with someone like you as her guide.”

“It could have been you.” Peter’s voice was muffled, but the man’s ears had not lost their sharpness, despite the added now-constant sound of his heartbeat drumming.

“It could never have been me, Pete-“ A sharp pain zipped through his body, and his eyes clenched shut. He swallowed – audibly, this time – the huge amount of blood which he was sure was trying to make its way out through his mouth, not back down again, and groaned, hands around Peter dropping to his sides and fists clenching.

Peter quickly sat up, wide eyes hurriedly scanning him. “Tony?” His voice broke. “Tony!”

Tony grabbed his wrist, breaths coming in short gasps as he tried to control it all. He was sure he could hear the people around him voicing their concern to each other, but he was also certain – and assured – that there were people there, such as Pepper and Steve, to stop them from trying to help him. He could not be helped. Did he even want it? His eyes shot open, immediately landing on Peter. “I love you,” he said, voice gravelly. He did not want to rush this, but he felt as though he was on a time limit here, and it was quickly coming to an end. “Always have. I’m sorry- for not showing it.”

Peter shook his head. “I knew it,” he said. “You did show it.” And he had. Every phone call made to check in on him, every hour spent out of his day working on the Spider Man suit, every penny he spent on him, every hug, every shared laugh, every smile… they’d all shown his love in the most discreet of ways, but they’d done it all the same, and Peter couldn’t have felt more grateful.

Tony smiled, and the kid tried his hardest to not be shocked at the blood that was quickly coating his lips. “I thought so.” He could barely hear his own voice, now. “Hey… thanks for all the dad practice you gave me. It really pro- proved useful.” He smiled faintly at the breathy laugh that escaped Peter’s lips.

“I’m glad,” he said, before hesitating. “Are you in pain?”

Pain. It had all gone, now. There’d been an agonising moment of it… but it’d faded. He felt… light. Like his soul was beginning to drift off, leaving the shell behind. There was no feeling of- of anything. He shifted slightly, shaking his head. “No.” Because you’re here with me. He coughed, blood dripping down from his mouth, and his face turned deathly white. Raging butterflies spawned out of nowhere in Peter’s stomach, and he leaned forward, hands coming to rest on Tony’s shoulders.

“Tony!” he called.

The warmth of Tony’s life was being swept away by the cold embrace of death, and yet this cold embrace felt welcoming. He was seconds away from it, now. He could see the light, and as soon as he touched it, as soon as his fingertips brushed across it, it turned warm. Comforting. It felt like he was going home.

“It’s been an honour, son.”

And, like the snap of two fingers, Tony Stark’s heart beat one last time.
